          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Mar 20, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<span class="line"><!---->This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crbug.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com"><!---->crbug.com<!----></a> searches for similar crashes.<span class="line"><!----> searches for similar crashes.<!----></span><br>Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<span class="line"><!---->Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<!----></span><br><br>I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<span class="line"><!---->I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<!----></span><br>When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<span class="line"><!---->When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<!----></span><br><br>More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<span class="line"><!---->More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<!----></span><br><br>The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<span class="line"><!---->The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<!----></span><br><br>IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<!----></span><br><br>windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<span class="line"><!---->windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<!----></span><br><br>READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <span class="line"><!---->READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <!----></span><br><br>ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<span class="line"><!---->ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br>FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<span class="line"><!---->FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<span class="line"><!---->See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<!----></span><br>1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<span class="line"><!---->1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<!----></span><br>2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<span class="line"><!---->2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<!----></span><br>3. Wait (+ ???)<span class="line"><!---->3. Wait (+ ???)<!----></span><br>4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<span class="line"><!---->4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<!----></span><br>5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<span class="line"><!---->5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<!----></span><br>Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<!----></span><br><br>FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<span class="line"><!---->Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<!----></span><br>Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<span class="line"><!---->Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<!----></span><br>Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<span class="line"><!---->Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        In case it matters, Tab 1 was on "<span class="line"><!---->In case it matters, Tab 1 was on "<!----></span>https://app.{websiteA}.com/path1...<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://app.{websiteA}.com/path1..."><!---->https://app.{websiteA}.com/path1...<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> while the link that opened Tab 3 is "<span class="line"><!----> while the link that opened Tab 3 is "<!----></span>http://{subdomain}.{websiteA}.com/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://{subdomain}.{websiteA}.com/"><!---->http://{subdomain}.{websiteA}.com/<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> (note the different subdomain and protocol difference) which then redirects to "<span class="line"><!----> (note the different subdomain and protocol difference) which then redirects to "<!----></span>https://app.{websiteA}.com/path2...<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://app.{websiteA}.com/path2..."><!---->https://app.{websiteA}.com/path2...<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> (same origin, diff path as Tab 1). I'm not certain when the Tab 3 crash occurred exactly, whether on the first URL, or on the second URL, or prior to any navigation.<span class="line"><!----> (same origin, diff path as Tab 1). I'm not certain when the Tab 3 crash occurred exactly, whether on the first URL, or on the second URL, or prior to any navigation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Mar 20, 2023)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Mar 20, 2023)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Mar 20, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->

      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<span class="line"><!---->This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crbug.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com"><!---->crbug.com<!----></a> searches for similar crashes.<span class="line"><!----> searches for similar crashes.<!----></span><br>Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<span class="line"><!---->Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<!----></span><br><br>I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<span class="line"><!---->I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<!----></span><br>When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<span class="line"><!---->When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<!----></span><br><br>More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<span class="line"><!---->More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<!----></span><br><br>The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<span class="line"><!---->The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<!----></span><br><br>IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<!----></span><br><br>windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<span class="line"><!---->windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<!----></span><br><br>READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <span class="line"><!---->READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <!----></span><br><br>ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<span class="line"><!---->ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br>FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<span class="line"><!---->FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<span class="line"><!---->See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<!----></span><br>1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<span class="line"><!---->1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<!----></span><br>2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<span class="line"><!---->2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<!----></span><br>3. Wait (+ ???)<span class="line"><!---->3. Wait (+ ???)<!----></span><br>4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<span class="line"><!---->4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<!----></span><br>5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<span class="line"><!---->5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<!----></span><br>Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<!----></span><br><br>FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<span class="line"><!---->Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<!----></span><br>Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<span class="line"><!---->Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<!----></span><br>Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<span class="line"><!---->Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

The page was rendered so the tab hadn't crashed yet at this point. Then I did one of the following (can't remember exactly): I either scrolled down or refreshed the page after it had loaded. Immediately after performing that action (one or both of: scrolling down or refreshing page), the STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION error appeared on the CloudWatch pricing tab and the other 2 AWS Console tabs I had open also crashed with same error (so I assume they shared the same renderer process since they're same-site).<span class="line"><!----> to open it on new tab, then switched to the 3rd tab using ctrl+tab.         Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Mar 20, 2023)
      </option>

      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<span class="line"><!---->This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crbug.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com"><!---->crbug.com<!----></a> searches for similar crashes.<span class="line"><!----> searches for similar crashes.<!----></span><br>Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<span class="line"><!---->Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<!----></span><br><br>I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<span class="line"><!---->I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<!----></span><br>When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<span class="line"><!---->When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<!----></span><br><br>More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<span class="line"><!---->More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<!----></span><br><br>The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<span class="line"><!---->The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<!----></span><br><br>IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<!----></span><br><br>windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<span class="line"><!---->windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<!----></span><br><br>READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <span class="line"><!---->READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <!----></span><br><br>ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<span class="line"><!---->ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br>FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<span class="line"><!---->FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<span class="line"><!---->See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<!----></span><br>1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<span class="line"><!---->1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<!----></span><br>2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<span class="line"><!---->2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<!----></span><br>3. Wait (+ ???)<span class="line"><!---->3. Wait (+ ???)<!----></span><br>4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<span class="line"><!---->4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<!----></span><br>5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<span class="line"><!---->5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<!----></span><br>Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<!----></span><br><br>FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<span class="line"><!---->Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<!----></span><br>Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<span class="line"><!---->Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<!----></span><br>Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<span class="line"><!---->Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        In case it matters, Tab 1 was on "<span class="line"><!---->In case it matters, Tab 1 was on "<!----></span>https://app.{websiteA}.com/path1...<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://app.{websiteA}.com/path1..."><!---->https://app.{websiteA}.com/path1...<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> while the link that opened Tab 3 is "<span class="line"><!----> while the link that opened Tab 3 is "<!----></span>http://{subdomain}.{websiteA}.com/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://{subdomain}.{websiteA}.com/"><!---->http://{subdomain}.{websiteA}.com/<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> (note the different subdomain and protocol difference) which then redirects to "<span class="line"><!----> (note the different subdomain and protocol difference) which then redirects to "<!----></span>https://app.{websiteA}.com/path2...<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://app.{websiteA}.com/path2..."><!---->https://app.{websiteA}.com/path2...<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> (same origin, diff path as Tab 1). I'm not certain when the Tab 3 crash occurred exactly, whether on the first URL, or on the second URL, or prior to any navigation.<span class="line"><!----> (same origin, diff path as Tab 1). The page was rendered so the tab hadn't crashed yet at this point. Then I did one of the following (can't remember exactly): I either scrolled down or refreshed the page after it had loaded. Immediately after performing that action (one or both of: scrolling down or refreshing page), the STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION error appeared on the CloudWatch pricing tab and the other 2 AWS Console tabs I had open also crashed with same error (so I assume they shared the same renderer process since they're same-site).<span class="line"><!----> to open it on new tab, then switched to the 3rd tab using ctrl+tab.       VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<span class="line"><!---->This sounds like a potential memory issue based on observed behavior and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crbug.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com"><!---->crbug.com<!----></a> searches for similar crashes.<span class="line"><!----> searches for similar crashes.<!----></span><br>Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<span class="line"><!---->Found this on Stable, have crash dump and some context. Still trying to repro again.<!----></span><br><br>I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<span class="line"><!---->I had a background tab open on WebsiteA ("Tab 1") and an email tab on WebsiteB ("Tab 2"). I stepped away from laptop for 30-60 minutes (on Windows lockscreen the whole time).<!----></span><br>When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<span class="line"><!---->When I returned, from my email I opened a link to WebsiteA using ctrl+click (to open link in new background tab) which created "Tab 3". After a couple of seconds I switched to the new tab (Tab 3) for WebsiteA, and saw it was in a crashed state.<!----></span><br><br>More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<span class="line"><!---->More interestingly, I then switched to the original tab for WebsiteA (Tab 1) and the page was blank (instead of an error page indicating a renderer kill). I then looked at Chrome's Task Manager to see if the renderer process for WebsiteA was still running, but as far as I could tell it was not (or at least not associated with the tab page's title). I refreshed the page which then loaded the original page on Tab 1 normally.<!----></span><br><br>The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<span class="line"><!---->The blank page on Tab 1 suggests to me that the renderer for Tab 1 went away somehow either before or after the crash of Tab 3. How or why is a mystery. I suspect Tab 3 tried to use the renderer process for Tab 1 (as expected, since it's same origin), but since something happened to Tab 1's renderer process, that led to the bad memory read on Tab 3.<!----></span><br><br>IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the error shown in the crashed Tab 3 was STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION (or something else which wasn't a breakpoint) which prompted me to look into it further.<!----></span><br><br>windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<span class="line"><!---->windbg !analyze output suggests a non-null read, but unsure why/where without symbolized stack trace (which I don't have because it was on Stable, not ASan). See attached windbg-analysis.txt for full output and attached dump.<!----></span><br><br>READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <span class="line"><!---->READ_ADDRESS:  000002e6015b0100 <!----></span><br><br>ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<span class="line"><!---->ERROR_CODE: (NTSTATUS) 0xc0000005 - The instruction at 0x%p referenced memory at 0x%p. The memory could not be %s.<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_CODE_STR:  c0000005<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER1:  0000000000000000<!----></span><br><br>EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<span class="line"><!---->EXCEPTION_PARAMETER2:  000002e6015b0100<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br>FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<span class="line"><!---->FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  INVALID_POINTER_READ_c0000005_chrome.dll!Unknown<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 111.0.5563.65 Stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2728)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<span class="line"><!---->See description above for context. Don't have exact repro steps at the moment, but vaguely:<!----></span><br>1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<span class="line"><!---->1. Open tab to WebsiteA ("Tab 1")<!----></span><br>2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<span class="line"><!---->2. Open tab to WebsiteB ("Tab 2") with link to WebsiteA<!----></span><br>3. Wait (+ ???)<span class="line"><!---->3. Wait (+ ???)<!----></span><br>4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<span class="line"><!---->4. On WebsiteB (Tab 2), ctrl+click link to WebsiteA to open new background tab ("Tab 3")<!----></span><br>5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<span class="line"><!---->5. Switch to new background tab (Tab 3)<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Tab 3 shows error page, Tab 1 is blank<!----></span><br>Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Page in Tab 3 loaded normally, Tab 1 is shown normally<!----></span><br><br>FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<span class="line"><!---->Type of crash: Renderer (tab)<!----></span><br>Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<span class="line"><!---->Crash State: Will attach dmp and windbg analysis in comment<!----></span><br>Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<span class="line"><!---->Client ID (if relevant): 795a64cb3813584e (crash ID from chrome://crashes)<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 4<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1426269#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by

        I think this same issue repro'd again. Renderer process for 3 tabs crashed with error page saying STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION.<span class="line"><!---->I think this same issue repro'd again. The page was rendered so the tab hadn't crashed yet at this point. Then I did one of the following (can't remember exactly): I either scrolled down or refreshed the page after it had loaded. Immediately after performing that action (one or both of: scrolling down or refreshing page), the STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION error appeared on the CloudWatch pricing tab and the other 2 AWS Console tabs I had open also crashed with same error (so I assume they shared the same renderer process since they're same-site).<span class="line"><!----> to open it on new tab, then switched to the 3rd tab using ctrl+tab.               <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;

        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

      </button>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement.

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
